Instrument_Host.name: MINERVA-II2 Rover-2 ULULA
Instrument_Host.description: MINERVA-II is the successor to the original MINERVA robot installed on the Hayabusa spacecraft, consisting of two units: MINERVA-II1 and MINERVA-II2. The latter includes Rover-2, which is also referred to as ULULA (University-made Landing Unit for Locomotion on Asteroid) after its landing on Ryugu. Rover-2's primary objective is to explore efficient movement on the asteroid through various hopping mechanisms. It features four actuators that utilize different methods for hopping, including centrifugal force, permanent magnets, temperature-induced bi-metal action, and elastic energy from leaf springs. The rover is equipped with two MICAM cameras, six temperature sensors, two accelerometers, and six photodiodes to help determine its orientation by detecting sunlight.
